red_flags.symptom: Severe abdominal pain or persistent vomiting
red_flags.action: Immediate IV fluids, monitor for dengue hemorrhagic fever

red_flags.symptom: Bleeding (epistaxis, gum bleeding, blood in vomit/stool)
red_flags.action: Admit to hospital, monitor platelet count and hematocrit

red_flags.symptom: Signs of plasma leakage (pleural effusion, ascites)

red_flags.action: Check for dengue shock syndrome, aggressive fluid resuscitation
Hospital admission, platelet transfusion if active bleeding

criteria: Travel to or residence in dengue-endemic area

treatment_algorithm.title: Classify Dengue Severity
treatment_algorithm.description: Use WHO 2009 classification to guide management
special_considerations: Group A (Dengue without warning signs): Can be managed at home
Group B (Dengue with warning signs): Requires hospital observation
Group C (Severe dengue): Requires ICU admission and aggressive management
Warning signs: abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, mucosal bleeding, lethargy, liver enlargement, rising hematocrit with falling platelets

treatment_algorithm.title: Group A: Outpatient Management

medications.name: Paracetamol
medications.dosage: 500-1000 mg for adults, 15 mg/kg for children

treatment_algorithm.follow_up: Daily clinic visit or phone check during critical phase (days 3-7)
special_considerations: AVOID: Aspirin, NSAIDs, IM injections (bleeding risk)
Return immediately if warning signs develop

treatment_algorithm.title: Group B: Hospital Observation
treatment_algorithm.follow_up: Monitor vitals every 1-2 hours, hematocrit every 6-12 hours
special_considerations: Titrate IV fluids based on clinical response
If hematocrit stable and improving: reduce fluids to 3-5 mL/kg/h
If hematocrit rising: increase fluids to 5-10 mL/kg/h
Watch for fluid overload: stop IV when hematocrit normalizing and adequate oral intake

treatment_algorithm.title: Group C: Severe Dengue (ICU)
treatment_algorithm.description: For dengue shock syndrome or severe organ impairment

medications.name: IV Crystalloid Bolus
medications.frequency: Repeat up to 3 times if needed

treatment_algorithm.follow_up: Hourly vital signs, hematocrit every 4-6 hours
special_considerations: If shock persists after 3rd bolus: consider colloid (albumin or plasma)
Do NOT give platelets prophylactically (only if < 10,000 with bleeding)
Monitor for complications: pulmonary edema, ARDS, acute liver failure

distinguishing_features: Joint pain can persist for months

complications.name: Dengue hemorrhagic fever
complications.management: Aggressive IV fluid resuscitation, platelet transfusion if severe bleeding

complications.name: Dengue shock syndrome
complications.prevention: Timely IV fluid therapy when warning signs appear
complications.management: Crystalloid bolus 10-20 mL/kg, repeat up to 3 times, then colloid if needed

complications.name: Acute liver failure
complications.management: Supportive care, may require liver transplant if fulminant

complications.name: Encephalopathy
complications.prevention: Maintain adequate perfusion, correct metabolic abnormalities
complications.management: Supportive ICU care, treat underlying cause

prevention.effectiveness: Removing stagnant water reduces Aedes mosquito population by 70-90%

prevention.intervention: Personal protection (repellents, long sleeves, bed nets)
prevention.target_population: Individuals in endemic areas during outbreaks
Individuals 9-45 years with previous dengue infection
prevention.effectiveness: Reduces severe dengue by 80%, only for seropositive individuals
Reduces mortality from 20% to < 1% with proper fluid management

references.title: WHO Dengue Guidelines for diagnosis, treatment, prevention and control
Comprehensive guideline for prevention and control of dengue and dengue haemorrhagic fever
